description.narrative: WLSA is a Mozambican research and study organization specializing in gender. WLSA is a feminist organization, well known in the Mozambican civil society panorama. Through its experience and capacity for data collection and analysis, it will bring added value to the program in terms of understanding and integrating gender on agriculture. WLSA will be the lead on research regarding gender poweranalysis, power relation and decision making on the beneficiaries. The research will be 3: the baseline, mid-term and final, in accordance to the timetable of project implementation, it means 2017, 2019 and 2021. This periodic researches will be important for understand the evolution and changes on the life of the beneficiaries.

participating-org.narrative: WLSA is a Mozambican research and study organization specializing in gender. Through its experience and capacity for data collection and analysis, it will bring added value to the program in terms of understanding and integrating gender issues. In the three-research cycle (2017/2019 and 2021), it is proposed to articulate the results of the study with each of the other dimensions of the program, namely with the change of behavior regarding gender equality, so as to enable peasant women to intervene, not only in increasingproduction (Learning new techniques) but also in decision-making. This is intended to empower women to recognize what constrains them in relation to the exercise of power and to engage in change, which begins at the individual level, based on an awareness of gender inequalities on the part of women and men. The transformation of power relations between men and women can only take place if there are individual changes in perception and attitudes: women's better self-esteem, openness of men to concerted decisions, and the sharing of tasks. This will give women more freedom to choose their activities, to train, to move, to generate income and to manage them. Civil society organizations have a key role to play in these transformations witha significant impact on the rural communities of the province as they themselves are able to enhance their gender sensitivity and take ownership of the participatory approaches to induce these changes, in order to Reproduce them in the target group. It is hoped that the various components of this program willtranslate into increased women smallholder farm incomes generated and managed by the rural women in Nampula province through their insertion into local and sustainable agricultural value chains. The objectives of the research are: (i) to identify socio-economic and cultural obstacles that constrain women's access to decision-making processes, particularly those related to production and income; (ii) Activities undertaken in the first two years of the program (2017 and 2018) and (iii) in evaluating the effects of the program on changes in the behavior of direct beneficiaries and in formulating recommendations to increase women's intervention at different levels of decision-making. The first survey will serve as the Baseline of the Program. The methodology of this research is developed around three dimensions: The first is a brief review of the research carried out in Mozambique on access to land for women peasants and on the obstacles to decision-making on production and income; The second dimension is the analysis of the legislation and public policies in force in Mozambique on access and use of land, from a gender perspective, by consulting the most recent informationat the national level - for example Mozambique's Gender Profile, and data The country and the province of Nampula; The third dimension consists of semi-structured, individual and focus group interviews that will enable each level of the research cycle to recognize the central elements that are obstacles to women's intervention in the production and market access processes, and to identify theComponents that may increase the power of decision making. Semi-structured interviews should allow the collection of numerical datato serve as a baseline within MEAL; A fourth dimension is the collection of data on the current situation of peasant women - beneficiaries / non-beneficiaries of the Program - with regard to: access to means of production, decision-making power, economic activities, financial management, Logical of the Program. The target groups for the surveys are peasant women's commissions in the districtsof Monapo, Malema and Ribáue and other associations of peasant women. The peasant associations that frame men and womenas well as the civil society associations operating at each of these space units will also be taken as reference groups. Local authorities will be privileged to obtain information on issues that relate to the region's socio-economic organization. The surveys will be qualitative and will consider, in the collection of data, indicators inspired by the Logical Framework and the ToC of the Program, namely: number of associations and associated women; Access to land and DUAT; Women in commercial and profitable activities; Access to micro-credit; Access to technical and managerial knowledge; Integration of women into local and sustainable agricultural value chains; Access to seeds, inputs, production materials; Women with knowledge and use of rights; Women with greater capacity for influence and mensharing activities and decisions with women; Changes in cultural practices.
